TI_TEXT.P: Εξοπλισμός ασφαλείας (π.χ. έναντι κλοπής, πυρκαγιάς κ.λπ.)

TITLE.P: Supply and Commissioning of Hold Baggage Scanning (HBS) Equipment and Provision of Support and Maintenance Services.

SHORT_DESCR.P: MAG awarded a contract to the Supplier on 23.3.2016, for the supply of hold baggage scanning equipment meeting Standard 3 (‘HBS’) plus support and maintenance (‘Contract’).
MAG has a time-limited statutory obligation to install HBS at its airports.

MAG also arranged an alternative supply of HBS (plus support and maintenance) in March 2016. The alternative arrangement has now been terminated due to a failure to deliver, leaving MAG with a supply gap, arising late in the programmed delivery period. This seriously threatens MAG's ability to meet its statutory obligations.
MAG is modifying the Contract to cover the gap and mitigate the impact of the failure.

The non-binding indicative forecast in the Contract relates to MAG's airports at Manchester, Bournemouth and East Midlands. To cover the supply gap, MAG has revised that forecast to include additional HBS machines at East Midlands and HBS machines at Stansted, including support and maintenance in both cases.

The Contract relates to HBS machines for 4 different applications. In the original procurement procedure, these were divided into 4 lots, but all of the HBS machines to be supplied by the Supplier are included within a single contractual arrangement. The Contract defines the HBS machines and specifies lead times and a purchase order process, with MAG to issue purchase orders in accordance with its requirements for HBS machines. The Contract includes a non-binding indicative forecast of MAG's requirements for HBS machines, delivery dates and delivery locations. However, MAG is entitled to revise the number of machines, delivery dates and delivery locations from time to time. The Supplier must accept all purchase orders issued by MAG. To issue purchase orders in accordance with the revised forecast, MAG considers it necessary to add pricing detail to the Contract to reflect the additional HBS machines at East Midlands and HBS machines at Stansted plus support and maintenance.

OPTIONS_DESCR.P: The Contract includes options to extend the product order period and the overall term. These are not changed by the minor modifications that are the subject of this notice.

INFO_ADD.P: Lot 1 HBS machines are ECAC certified and DfT approved Standard 3 EDS machines for processing ingauge baggage with a minimum throughput capacity of 1 000 bags per hour, based on an average bag length of 750 mm.
The minor modifications that are the subject of this notice include an estimated 8 additional Lot 1 HBS machines (3 currently intended for East Midlands, 5 currently intended for Stansted).

SHORT_DESCR.P: The Contract relates to HBS machines for 4 different applications. In the original procurement procedure, these were divided into 4 lots, but all of the HBS machines to be supplied by the Supplier are included within a single contractual arrangement. The Contract defines the HBS machines and specifies lead times and a purchase order process, with MAG to issue purchase orders in accordance with its requirements for HBS machines. The Contract includes a non-binding indicative forecast of MAG's requirements for HBS machines, delivery dates and delivery locations. However, MAG is entitled to revise the number of machines, delivery dates and delivery locations from time to time. The Supplier must accept all purchase orders issued by MAG. To issue purchase orders in accordance with the revised forecast, MAG considers it necessary to add pricing detail to the Contract to reflect the HBS machines at Stansted plus support and maintenance.

OPTIONS_DESCR.P: The Contract includes options to extend the product order period and the overall term. These are not changed by the minor modifications that are the subject of this notice.

INFO_ADD.P: Lot 2 HBS machines are ECAC certified and DfT approved Standard 3 EDS machines for processing out of gauge baggage with a minimum throughput capacity of 180 bags per hour based on an average bag length of 2 000 mm.
The minor modifications that are the subject of this notice include an estimated 2 additional Lot 2 HBS machines (currently intended for Stansted).

SHORT_DESCR.P: The minor modifications that are the subject of this notice do not relate to the Lot 3 HBS machines.

OPTIONS_DESCR.P: The minor modifications that are the subject of this notice do not relate to the Lot 3 HBS machines.

INFO_ADD.P: Lot 3 HBS machines are ECAC certified and DfT approved Standard 3 EDS machines for processing in gauge baggage with a minimum throughput capacity of 300 bags per hour and a maximum machine footprint of 3.0 m (Length) x 1.7 m (Width) x 1.7 m (Height).

SHORT_DESCR.P: The minor modifications that are the subject of this notice do not relate to the Lot 4 HBS machines.

OPTIONS_DESCR.P: The minor modifications that are the subject of this notice do not relate to the Lot 4 HBS machines.

INFO_ADD.P: Lot 4 HBS machines are ECAC certified and DfT approved Standard 3 EDS machines for processing out of gauge baggage with a minimum throughput capacity of 180 bags per hour and a maximum machine footprint of 3.0 m (Length) x 1.7 m (Width) x 1.7 m (Height).

D_JUSTIFICATION.P: The constituent elements of the additional pricing described in II.2.4 (Lots 1 and 2) will be unit costs already in the Contract (being uniform across the airports). The only exception to this is a higher unit cost for fully comprehensive maintenance at Stansted due to the absence of on-site technicians.

The pricing additions are minor modifications to the Contract. To the extent that such modifications are needed, these do not require a new procurement procedure in accordance with Directive 2014/25/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council , as implemented by the Utilities Contracts Regulations 2016. The modifications are not substantial within the meaning of Regulation 88(7). The modifications do not: (a) render the Contract materially different in character from the one initially concluded; (b) introduce conditions which, had they been part of the initial procurement procedure, would have: (i) allowed for the admission of other candidates than those initially selected; (ii) allowed for the acceptance of a tender other than that originally accepted; or (iii) attracted additional participants in the procurement procedure; (c) change the economic balance of the Contract in favour of the Supplier in a manner which was not provided for in the initial Contract; nor (d) extend the scope of the Contract considerably.
The initial estimated value of the Contract was 39 400 000 GBP. The modifications described in this notice are currently expected to increase that value, up to an estimated 51 500 000 GBP.

Further, in the event that any 1 or more of the modifications to the Contract is considered to be a substantial modification within the meaning of Regulation 88(7), the Contract may be modified in that way without a new procurement procedure because the need for modification has been brought about by circumstances which a diligent utility could not have foreseen and that modification does not alter the overall nature of the contract (in compliance with Regulation 88(1)(c)). The relevant unforeseen circumstances are the failure of the alternative supply of HBS machines, arising late in the programmed delivery period, resulting in a supply gap, and the consequent serious threat to MAG's ability to meet its statutory obligations.

For the purposes of compliance with Regulation 88(1)(c), MAG regards this notice as also constituting a Regulation 88(2) modification notice, containing the information set out in Annex XVI to Directive 2014/25/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council .

ADDRESS_REVIEW_BODY.OFFICIALNAME: Not applicable, but proceedings may be started in the High Court of England and Wales in accordance with Part 5 (Remedies) of the Utilities Contracts Regulations 2016

REVIEW_PROCEDURE.P: In accordance with Part 5 (Remedies) of the Utilities Contracts Regulations 2016.
